t: Isaiah 23
An Oracle Concerning Tyre and Sidon
The*p oracle concerning Tyre. Wail,*pn O ships of Tarshish, for*ld Tyre is laid waste, without house or harbor! From*ln the land of Cyprus it*ld is revealed to them.
Be*ln still, O inhabitants of the coast; the*ld merchants of Sidon, who cross the sea, have filled you.
And*ln on many waters your*ln revenue was the grain of Shihor, the*ld harvest of the Nile; you*ld were the merchant of the nations.
Be*ln ashamed, O Sidon, for the sea has spoken, the*ld stronghold of the sea, saying: “I*ln have neither labored nor given birth, I*ld have neither reared young men nor*ld brought up young women.”
When*ln the report comes to Egypt, they*ld will be in anguish over the report about Tyre.
Cross*ln over to Tarshish; wail,*ld O inhabitants of the coast!
Is*ln this your exultant city whose*ld origin is from days of old, whose*ln feet carried her to*ld settle far away?
Who*ln has purposed this against*ld Tyre, the bestower of crowns, whose*ln merchants were princes, whose*ld traders were the honored of the earth?
The*ln Lord*s of hosts has purposed it, to*ld defile the pompous pride of all glory, to*ld dishonor all the honored of the earth.
Cross*ln over your land like the Nile, O*ld daughter of Tarshish; there*ld is no restraint anymore.
He*ln has stretched out his hand over the sea; he*ld has shaken the kingdoms; the*ln Lord*s has given command concerning Canaan to*ld destroy its strongholds.
And*ln he said: “You*ln will no more exult, O*ld oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon; arise,*ln cross over to Cyprus, even*ld there you will have no rest.”
Behold*p the land of the Chaldeans! This is the people that was not; Assyria destined it for wild beasts. They erected their siege towers, they stripped her palaces bare, they made her a ruin.
Wail,*pn O ships of Tarshish, for*ld your stronghold is laid waste.
In*p that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the prostitute:
“Take*pn a harp; go*ld about the city, O*ld forgotten prostitute! Make*ln sweet melody; sing*ld many songs, that*ld you may be remembered.”
At*p the end of seventy years, the Lord*s will visit Tyre, and she will return to her wages and will prostitute herself with all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth.
Her merchandise and her wages will be holy to the Lord.*s It will not be stored or hoarded, but her merchandise will supply abundant food and fine clothing for those who dwell before the Lord.*s
